title: 104_s1606
content: The "Biological Agents Enhanced Penalties and Control Act" aims to regulate the transfer and possession of hazardous biological agents to protect public health and safety. It acknowledges the potential threat these agents pose for terrorism and criminal activities while ensuring access for legitimate clinical and research purposes. The "Biological Agents Enhanced Penalties and Control Act" amends Chapter 10 of title 18, United States Code to include penalties for attempts, threats, or conspiracies related to biological weapons. It expands the definition to include bioengineered components and toxic materials from plants, animals, and microorganisms. The "Biological Agents Enhanced Penalties and Control Act" expands the definition of biological weapons to include bioengineered components and toxic materials from plants, animals, microorganisms, viruses, fungi, or infectious substances. It also includes recombinant molecules and biological products resulting from biotechnology. The "Biological Agents Enhanced Penalties and Control Act" broadens the definition of biological weapons to encompass bioengineered components and toxic materials from various sources, including microorganisms, viruses, and infectious substances. Additionally, it includes recombinant molecules and biological products derived from biotechnology. In relation to terrorism, amendments are made to Section 2332a(a) of title 18, United States Code, to include threats and the use of biological agents, toxins, or vectors for destruction. The "Biological Agents Enhanced Penalties and Control Act" expands the definition of biological weapons to include bioengineered components and toxic materials. It also covers recombinant molecules and biological products from biotechnology. The Secretary will establish a list of biological agents with severe public health threats based on criteria like human health effects, contagiousness, and availability of treatments. The Secretary will regulate the transfer of listed biological agents by establishing safety procedures, including training and laboratory requirements, to prevent unauthorized access for harmful use. The Secretary will regulate the transfer of biological agents to prevent unauthorized access for harmful use, establish safeguards against terrorism, ensure public safety during transfers, and provide access for research and education purposes within specified time limits. The final rules must be issued within 360 days of the enactment of this Act. Definitions include "biological agent" as defined in section 178 of title 18, United States Code, and "Secretary" as the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
